author: Anita Rachman
title: Uber-Killer Grab, Go-Jek Aren’t Just Tech Firms, Indonesia Says
text:
1 COMMENTS JAKARTA, Indonesia—The Indonesian government said Monday that ride-hailing firms Grab Inc. and PT Go-Jek Indonesia must be registered as transportation companies to ensure safety and provide job protections for their drivers.
The move removes the option for the firms to be designated as technology companies, which facilitated easier use of drivers as partners and sparked resistance from traditional taxi operators and, increasingly, their own drivers.
A woman rides on a Go-Jek motorcycle taxi. Photo: garry lotulung/Reuters Related 
Uber Sells Southeast Asia Business to Rival Grab Uber Battles Ride-Sharing Startups in SoftBank ‘Family’ Uber’s Latest Retreat Leaves Brazil, India as the Key Battlegrounds The new regulations followed the latest in a series of protests by thousands of drivers last week who wanted their employment status made more clear, including obligations to assist drivers in cases of accidents or thefts.
Go-Jek said Monday that the idea to change its status from an application to a transportation company is “a matter that requires in-depth study.” The company said a thorough study is needed to ensure the growth of digital economy in the country.
Grab didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.
The companies dominate the ride-hailing market in Southeast Asia’s largest economy and have made major inroads against established taxi companies and the mostly independent-operator motorcycle taxis called ojeks.
Singapore-based Grab took a major step last week when it acquired the Southeast Asian business of U.S. ride-hailing giant Uber Technologies Inc. Competition authorities in several countries have said they are on the alert for any sign of anticompetitive behavior.
Transportation minister Budi Karya Sumadi told a press briefing that the ministry will meet the two companies to discuss the transition from tech middlemen to transportation firms in coming days. Mr. Sumadi said the change will enable drivers to “directly communicate with the companies.”
Indonesia has struggled for more than two years to regulate ride-hailing companies, issuing a series of regulations to ensure the safety of drivers and customers and to meet complaints from traditional taxi firms who say their new rivals are evading costlier rules.
Both firms have expanded rapidly. They offer not only transportation services, but many more including food deliveries. Go-Jek, an Indonesian company, even offers massage and cleaning services.
The new regulation concerns only cars used as online taxis. But the huge numbers of motorcycle-taxi drivers who wear the colorful Grab and Go-Jek jackets are also asking for government help in dealing with the firms, saying their compensation is inadequate.
Mr. Sumadi said Monday that the ministry will help mediate between the motorcycle-taxi drivers and the companies, but refused their request to set floor prices, stating that motorcycles aren’t official recognized as a mode of public transport.
Write to Anita Rachman at Anita.Rachman@wsj.com
